title: Who will be the next mayor of London?
preds:
Khan up by 9 in last minute poll.  Heavy turnout favors Khan, low turnout is in Goldsmith's favor.
http://www.theweek.co.uk/london-mayor-election-2016/62681/london-mayor-election-2016-sadiq-khan-leads-in-last-minute-poll

Looks like Khan is way ahead, and Goldsmith attempt to Trump him failed. http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/03/when-is-the-london-mayoral-election-should-i-vote-for-sadiq-khan/ "A recent YouGov poll gave the Labour candidate a 16-point lead among first-preference votes, with 48 per cent of support, followed by Mr Goldsmith on 32 per cent. When second-choice votes were reallocated, the split was 60 per cent support for Khan and 40 percent for Goldsmith. One bookmaker has put the odds of the Tory candidate winning the race at just 2 per cent."

Unfamiliar with London politics; noted that Sadiq is popular among other participants.  In the forum there is a reference to a 15 point lead of Khan; Muslim leadership appears to be a reasonable,  progressive move.

who would London want as PM?  Zac seems to have $ and connections.
Khan perceived as a worker which might appeal to Londoners. people's vote
In theory, Labour turnout could be a problem, but most likely not a fatal one.

Goldsmith's attempts to caste Khan as a radical Islam sympathizer have back-fired, making him look like a racist, and with polls only days away, he's hard pressed to turn popular opinion back in his favor. Khan, on the other hand, represents the burgeoning multi-ethnic minority population in London. He's looking like the futuristic candidate London wants.

Khan up by 20 in the latest 2 polls:
http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/805a7fb0-0acb-11e6-b0f1-61f222853ff3.html#axzz47Y7GMTy3
Surge in polling numbers for Khan as London's mayor :  https://uk.news.yahoo.com/muslim-favourite-run-london-racially-charged-campaign-092839903--sector.html

No change to forecast. 
An excellent nuanced, salient perspective on both Brexit & London Mayoral votes.http://www2.politicalbetting.com/index.php/archives/2016/05/02/if-zac-loses-london-and-the-brexiters-fail-it-will-say-a-lot-about-the-declining-influence-of-the-press/

I'm basing my prediction on the fact that their isn't much news on the subject. Khan's victory is practically a done deal. Considering it's "just London", no hay can be made from a made-up fight to the finish.
According to general news reports and GJP consensus.

I actually don't know much about London mayor elections but post seeing this question, I got to read a lot of articles on it. Seems heavily in favor of Sadiq Khan as it seems he is leading the opinion polls dramatically. Given the diverse population mix, I am not surprised this is happening. Would like to put a single digit probability for Zac Goldsmith, which drives my probability for Sadiq Khan at 91%

Polls still favor Khan by 15-20 points. But polls have been unreliable lately. After having gone through the last eights years with a mayor such as Boris Johnson, one can reliably expect the tide to turn in favor of a candidate that is in so many ways his opposite.
decrease after Khan statements on Livingstone
The polls have been consistently positive for Khan, and are increasing.
Sadiq's deft handling of the Ken Livingstone affair, more proof of Khan's political acumen. This had a chance to spread, and still may for Corbyn, but not for Sadiq.
Labour ought to win easily, but the latest internal row works against them
Zac just doesn't have the right stuff for this pedestrian job.  Boris Johnson did though.
Sadiq Khan has been dominating the public opinion polls.

I believe that Sadig Kahn is going to be the next mayor of London due to the positivity that he is bringing to the public. He is bringing awareness on topics like the equality of Muslin women in London. Kahn questions why women choose to wear a veil over their face, he fears that this is labeling a cultural difference in women who do wear veils. Making them appear different to others or be treated differently. Although the topic of banning full face veil in London has been brought up, Kahn has said that he is no one to tell others what to wear or how to live their life. I believe that his concern for the treatment of women in London is a great quality that he brings as a candidate. Although he is a an Islamic man, he;s personal beliefs don't interfere with the well being of others, even of a different culture. Another good quality that makes him a strong candidate are his beliefs of London, he states that there is no other city where he would rather raise his children.

I believe Sadiq Khan will be the next mayor of London because he is progressive in his ideals, and although he would be the first Muslim to become mayor in the UK, citizens of London are not phased by this. Sadiq supports a revolution for a city that supports those living in poverty, and a more efficient city. This touches on many of the desires of the London population.

"The latest YouGov poll for the London Evening Standard gives Khan a 20-point lead over his Tory rival in the final round of the contest" (theweek.co.uk).
"The Labour candidate is currently ahead in the polls and the clear favourite to replace Boris Johnson next month" (theweek.co.uk). http://www.theweek.co.uk/london-mayor-election-2016/62681/london-mayor-election-2016-lord-sugar-attacks-sadiq-khan
http://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/london-mayoral-election-zac-goldsmith-has-mountain-to-climb-as-sadiq-khan-stretches-poll-lead-a3230406.html
According to general news reports and GJP consensus.
Khan is positively regarded, and appears well ahead of other possible contenders.

Polls show large proportion of voters are unaware of the positions of the candidates, and the race is starting to attract more national attention so they will soon be introduced to these policies. Therefore the race is likely more uncertain than the current surveys suggesting strong aggregate preference for Khan
Other parties are not feasible. Goldsmith appears to be destroying his own campaign. Short time left so little risk of shakeup

"What does his poisonous, devious, dishonest campaign say about the “principled” Goldsmith’s judgment? Exactly what kind of man is he?"
http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/apr/21/zac-goldsmith-must-be-held-to-account-for-his-poisonous-london-mayor-campaign I am so disappointed with Goldsmith. While challenging, this is an election he could have won, and I never expected he would botch up the opportunity so badly. (Flip-flopping from ZG 65 / SK 35 to ZG 35 / SK 65.)
Telephone poll from 4/5 still shows Khan in the lead 55-45, well outside MOE of 2.8: http://www.comres.co.uk/polls/itv-news-london-lbc-london-mayoral-poll/
Goldsmith gone from an effete lacklustre  to a lively race baiting campaign.  Desperate.
updated after some monte carlo analysis based on 2nd round polls on Wiki and usual standard errors in polling for samples that big

http://www.oddschecker.com/politics/british-politics/london-mayoral-election-2016/next-mayor Current odds for SK are between 1/7 and 1/10 compared to between 5/1 and 4/1 for ZG. That would approximate to between 81 and 85% for Sadiq Khan.

Passage of time, polls still looking good for Khan. Not much potential for big slip ups now, and hard to imagine what they would look like. All we can really look for as a downside is a total polling disaster similar to the general election.

Labour is winning in London  Khan is leading polls and the type of election in London helps him. His 55% of second round votes (wiki) should translate to approx a 75% chance of having >50% votes which would give him the win

Cameron, using his most public platform, takes a deliberate stab at Khan. I don't suspect Goldsmith much appreciates Dodgy Dave's "assistance." -1 for ZG, +1 for SK.
https://www.juicebrighton.com/news/uk-news/1957846/pm-branded-racist-for-attack-on-labours-khan/ Not that Goldsmith hasn't brought this upon himself, but Cameron should have known better.

1% upward adjustment to my forecast. Updating w/ recent "par for the course" Campaign discourse: Kahn still has a v high probability to become London's next Mayor. A. Goldsmiths recent leaflets using "normal" English campaign terminology such as "divisive & radical" raise the ire of Labour MP Chuka Umunna calling attacks on Sadiq Kahn as "Islamaphobic".   Since Lynton Crosby, a so called expert in this area is running Goldsmith's campaign, there is a tinge of unnecessary "nastiness" to all of this. There is a v high likelihood  this type of campaign approach was/& is intended to have dissuading affect for those considering the Kahn ticket.   However, what is most unfortunate for most good Londoners that will actually vote for Mayor,  is that they continue to be further inundated w/  innuendo & negativity rather than hard facts on what can be done to improve present situation. I wonder what the voter turnout will be on this one ??
1. http://labourlist.org/2016/04/chuka-umunna-tories-london-campaign-would-make-donald-trump-proud/
2.http://www.london24.com/news/politics/chuka_umunna_just_compared_zac_goldsmith_to_donald_trump_1_4501623
According to general news reports and GJP consensus.

Moving up from 71% on 18 March to reflect change in bookmaker's odds, from 2/5 then to 1/6 now. Also, Goldsmith came across in a recent interview as out of touch with the common Londoner, not a good impression to give for a billionaire's son.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_mayoral_election,_2016#Opinion_polls
+ the betting markets
http://www.oddschecker.com/politics/british-politics/london-mayoral-election-2016/next-mayor
have SK between 80 and 88%.
Going in higher than consensus. The racism spat isn't going to help ZG, and he was already polling well behind.
I believe left leaning population in London will vote for a mayor to be a counter-balance to the Tories.
Mr. Khan seems most in tune with the voters and their wishes, also historically Labor Party is favored.
Business man with clear social outlook seems a good combination in a multicultural city.  Sadiq Khan fulfils this requirement.

Recent polls, from the wiki link below, show Khan with a slight lead over Goldsmith in the 1st round, and an even larger lead in an expected 2nd round vote. Goldsmith, at 40% or less, in the 1st round projections, does not appear to have a chance at collecting 50% for a 1st round victory.  The outcome then, is a likely runoff election between the top two candidates.  Kahn and Goldsmith.
Projections in the polls show Kahn with a larger projected lead over Goldsmith in the second round than he has in the 1st round.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_mayoral_election,_2016
Conservatives are viewed as a little more toxic, especially rich ones with overseas trusts, so could affect Goldsmith. Labour have avoided big mistakes in the last few weeks

Polls have Sadiq Khan with strong lead. 
http://www.theweek.co.uk/london-mayor-election-2016/62681/london-mayor-election-2016-polls-sadiq-khan-holds-onto-solid-lead

New polls show Sadik Kahn is 8 points ahead (up from 3 points in previous poll)
23% of of voters still undecided.
Slow news week on London Mayoral Elections.  Goldsmith came across as out of touch in quiz about London (soccer clubs, museums, tube stations).
Betting odds are strong in favor of Khan - PaddyPower = 88% PredictIt = 81c I overreacted to last week's news - so this week I will settle at 70 Khan-30 Goldsmith -as a mid-way point between the previous two weeks. http://www.standard.co.uk/news/mayor/sadiq-khan-eight-points-ahead-of-zac-goldsmith-in-latest-poll-a3217256.html
http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/apr/05/zac-goldsmith-fails-quiz-london-football-teams-tube-stations

Sadiq Khan is 8 points ahead in most polls
http://www.itv.com/news/london/2016-04-04/sadiq-khan-leads-polls-to-become-next-mayor/ Zac Goldsmith is struggling to keep up in the race to be London mayor
http://www.businessinsider.com/khan-maintains-eight-point-poll-lead-2016-4?r=UK&IR=T
Khan has been the people's favorite for quite some time now and shows no signs of slowing throughout his campaign.

Khan should be a strong favourite given the strength of Labour's London ground operation and his backstory. However, while Goldsmith is underwhelming, his campaign should be well resourced and is being advised by Lynton Crosby. The Conservative get the vote out campaign, focus on elderly and suburban votes, alongside Labour's disunity, may result in a closer result than many, including the polls, are anticipating.
Haven't tracked this for a while, but moving up a little after seeing @dominich's comment.  Gonna go take a look at the news and catch up. http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/197826

Upping Khan by a few points, largely in response to a dreadful and embarrassing radio interview on a London station given by Goldsmith today that made him appear out of touch in fairly basic and cringeworthy ways. (Not knowing the names of London football stadium, nor the layout of tube lines.). Maybe not a big deal overall (and more serious allegations are being made in some circles about Khan), but this sort of thing will boost instinctive perceptions that Goldsmith doesn't have a clue about the daily life of the city he seeks to represent.

Kahn I think is far and away the favorite for this.  His polls are fairly impressive, and even though his demographic is young (which lowers their likelihood of actually turning out to the polls) their sheer numbers seem to be enough to overcome that.  London as a city generally tends toward the labor party as well.  Additionally, electing a Muslim mayor given the current geopolitical climate would make a pretty dramatic statement. But perhaps the most damning thing for Goldsmith is Tory implications with the recent Panama papers.  The prime minister of Iceland is already being called out to resign, and I think Londoners are well informed enough for this to make significant waves in the election. http://www.theguardian.com/news/2016/apr/04/tory-donors-links-to-offshore-firms-revealed-in-leaked-panama-papers http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/london-mayor-election/mayor-of-london/12079857/Why-Sadiq-Khan-will-beat-Zac-Goldsmith-and-what-that-would-mean.html

POLLS
PaddyPower odds for SK are still 1/4= 80%
No new polls since March 21st
Social media (popular with younger voters) shows a swing towards Zac Goldsmith (75% positive mention) and negativity towards SK (53% positive mention).
What does this mean?  Goldsmith will be up in the next polls and Khan will be down. SECURITY
The Comres article shows that security is a concern - that poll was taken before the Brussels Airport and Transit attacks.  In my opinion Londoners will be even more concerned about security issues now.  ZG polls better on "keeping London Safe" ZG 31% to SK 24%.  
What does this mean?  Goldsmith will be up in the next polls and Khan will be down. TRANSIT
London Transit is a one of the top priorities for voters.  Sadiq Khan plans to freeze bus and tube fares.  While ZG plans to raise fares and invest in Transit. It is by no means certain.
What does this mean?  Khan will be down up the next polls and Goldsmith will be down. CAMPAIGNING
Last week I reported that Zac Goldsmith, has tried to link himself to Modi to influence Indian voters.  This week in the news, he has been accused of racially profiling voters by leafleting with message of "The Gujarati community makes London great. Closer ties between the UK and India have been a priority for me as prime minister".  These leaflets seems to have backfired, and recipients have taken to social media to protest.
Both candidates are under scrutiny for campaign donations - Sadik Khan is worse on this issue.
What does this mean? No change.  Constituents will consider this as politicians being politicians. SUMMARY
Taken together as a body - I think the next polls will show that this race is tighter than it looks right now.
I am bringing my prediction down to 60-40 (instead of 85-15).  I am still siding on the side of Khan because he is labor and London voters are by and large labor voters.   http://www.paddypower.com/bet/politics/other-politics/london-mayor

New poll (http://www.comres.co.uk/polls/itv-london-lbc-london-mayoral-poll-march-2016/), similar results to before: http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/163208 Gap closed slightly, but still outside MOE of 2.8.

I've only caught 2-3 extended interviews with Khan on TV, but I must say that a) he did not comport himself as well as I had expected, and b) the interviewers, intentionally or otherwise, had him on the defensive and he had no good answers. Such interviews may not matter to London voters, but I sense it is less what Goldsmith does well than how Khan does poorly that might make a difference. +1 for Goldsmith.
stepping a bit back... I can't really remember why I chose such extreme prediction before

Khan by a narrow majority. Goldsmith enjoys support among many influencers, including the Evening Standard newspaper, but London has always been a Labour stronghold. Londoner's voting have the savvy and experience to disengage national party politics from local delivery, so the Corbyn effect won't be as pronounced for either side. It will be a close race though.

In a search for disconfirming evidence, I came across this older article, which is worth serious consideration.
Together each of the points make a strong case.  The strongest issues are the generation gap and the second preference votes.
I am bringing my prediction down  10 points.
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/london-mayor-election/12080405/Why-Zac-Goldsmith-can-still-beat-Sadiq-Khan-to-be-Mayor-of-London.html

- In April 2015, the current Mayor Boris Johnson had a 61% approval rating based on an Evening Standard poll. Voters tend to vote in the same party if they are satisfied with the current leader. http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/apr/10/boris-johnson-magic-bullet-tories

Current consensus on GJopen is 80: 20 for SK, same odds on paddypower.com
No new polling data available - SK still 6 points ahead of ZG, with 25% undecided.
Some media coverage of Head of Labor party Jeremy Corbyn’s list of loyalty ranking of party members-SK is listed in the “hostile” group that Corbyn would be unable to control.  This could hurt SK.  
ZG put made a political gaffe by trying to associate himself with President Modi - a cheap tactic  to attract voters of Indian origin

Goldsmith's gotten quite a bit closer with the last poll. Moving in the opposite direction of the crowd now.

Based on a recent poll showing Khan at 32% with Goldsmith at 25%, the same margin as last time.  This reinforces my previous belief that Khan will prevail.  Will keep an eye on this and keep updating as the battle continues, but for now the lead is looking pretty certain.
Update to betting markets and to move above consensus.

Increasing Sadiq Khan by 1% for passage of time. With the polls being off at the last general elections and also to some extent the Scottish referendum, I don't want to go higher at this time. Betting markets mostly have Khan as a 2/5 favorite. http://www.oddschecker.com/politics/british-politics/london-mayoral-election-2016/next-mayor

although recent polling shows a very solid lead for Khan, and Khan is a solid candidate, & London a Labour-leaning city, I caution forecasters not to go overboard. Polling in the UK is in crisis right now after the horrible miss in the General Election in May, & London in particular is a tough city to poll I'd imagine - young, transient population, hard to identify exactly what the population is that you're supposed to be sampling. Few people have landlines any more. http://ukpollingreport.co.uk/blog/archives/9651

http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/mar/15/london-mayor-race-sadiq-khan-lead-holding-firm-says-new-poll ". . . Labour’s Sadiq Khan has a clear lead over his main rival Zac Goldsmith of the Conservatives, but that a lot of Londoners have still to make up their minds.  ". . . YouGov, puts Khan seven points ahead of Goldsmith . . .  - exactly the same margin he enjoyed in the last YouGov poll, which was conducted at the beginning of the year. Both have picked up one percentage point since then, putting Khan on 32% and Goldsmith on 25%. Strip out the undecideds and those who say they will not vote and the Labour man’s lead over the Tory stretches to nine points. ". . . Ukip’s Peter Whittle lies third on 5%, up 1% since January. Lib Dem Caroline Pidgeon (up 1%) and the Green Party’s Sian Berry (no change) are both on 3%. "Opinium’s [poll]. . .  gave Khan a five point first preference lead and a 55% to 45% advantage over Goldsmith in a second round run-off under the supplementary vote system. YouGov and Opinium produced the most accurate findings of the 2012 mayoral race, so the numbers look encouraging for Khan at this stage. " . . .  although “don’t knows” have fallen from 30% to 23% since January, they remain numerous.  . . . . even though London is Britain’s most pro-EU region after Scotland, there could be significant anti-EU feeling for the Brexit-backing Goldsmith to exploit against the strongly europhile Khan . . . . " . . . History suggests that a 40% turnout could be a pleasant surprise. Much remains uncertain. There’s still a long way to go. 
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Because the campaign on the referendum on the EU has just begun, I'm hesitant to change my forecast at this time.

Ok, i may have anchored very high SK= 95 
My prediction is probably too high given that the opinion polls show small margin.  But I'm going to risk it. But here are the new developments roundup since my last update:
Zac Goldsmith is backing Brexit - London is generally pro EU  - so many say that was a political suicide - but others are not convinced - see telegraph article - ZG is popular with outer Londoners, and UKIP voters
March 8 Opinion poll - shows SQ lead is 5 points 31% V 26% for ZG - Bloomberg  (25% undecided) Standard
ZG is using negative messaging.  SK is staying positive  - The guardian Also - Morrisey (Yes! The singer) is considering running on animal rights issues - he has until end of month to get on the ballot.   Sources considered:

other would be Sian Berry the Green Party candidate, as she's compelling and most convincing on the housing narrative
London is a majority Liberal city and Mr. Khan is well ahead in polls and will likely remain so until the election.
Updated based on new polls and Bayesian analysis.

http://www.cityam.com/236377/london-mayoral-election-2016-exclusive-new-poll-figures-show-zac-goldsmith-is-seen-as-being-more-pro-business-than-sadiq-khan-by-a-26-point-margin An Opinium poll out earlier this week put Khan five points ahead of Goldsmith among adult voters. Khan is also set to net twice as many second preference votes as Goldsmith, putting him on track to win the run-off by a margin of 55-45, according to Opinium.

Recent polls show solid robust lead for Khan. https://twitter.com/britainelects/status/707179657825751040 Can't see Goldsmith winning barring polling disaster, as per http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/elections/2016/03/could-polls-be-wrong-london
Religion will play a role, and the electorate are losing trust in the Labour Party and especially Jeremy Corbyn

The latest poll I could find is from Jan 4-6, and it had Khan leading 55-45 with n=1156, with an MOE=3. Thus, it had well over 95% certainty of Khan winning, but obviously polls change over time and can be biased. New polls or criticism of the YouGov poll would change my forecast.
SK will get minority support. ZG will be seen by the majority as a capitalist looking after his own interests

Yougov Jan poll (which doesn’t add up to 100%):
Khan 31% + 5 = 36%
Goldsmith 24% + 7 = 31%
UKIP 4%
Green 3%
Lib 2%
Galloway 2%
Undecided 32% I have reassigned UKIP & Green votes to Zac, and Lib-Dem and Galloway votes to Khan. There are lots of undecideds, who will decide the election. Zac needs to outperform the Tory vote in London (as Boris did).  Sadiq needs to preserve the Labour vote (which he is likely to be better at than the quite divisive Ken). At the moment, Sadiq has to be the frontrunner, but the race is still (just about) winnable for Zac.

Gjopen 75%, Paddy Power 75% Odds checker 73% = Average = 74%
http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/jan/10/london-mayor-race-can-zac-goldsmith-catch-sadiq-khan
Sadiq Khan is the labor candidate, London is a labor stronghold.  
Polls  show Khan with a 6 point lead over Zac Goldsmith (Silver Spoon Conservative)
http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/jan/10/london-mayor-race-can-zac-goldsmith-catch-sadiq-khan
There are 3 months to go and 30% of voters are undecided, it isn't so safe to say he has a 74% chance to win.
Also taking into consideration the fact that Boris Johnson won London Mayor, he is a conservative and he was behind in the polls.
No polls, no real news, nothing to go by except bookies.

http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/jan/10/london-mayor-race-can-zac-goldsmith-catch-sadiq-khan Upping the Khan preference from January YouGov poll data, and momentum build from Nov-Jan. With 100 days to go, it would seem a very strong position (and heritage Labour London support) for Khan here.

No other candidate will win, this is very obvious. There is precedent for an independent win, but no such candidate seems to be stepping forward. The fundamentals favour Khan. London is a Labour city, comfortably winning the city in 2015 in spite of a national loss. It is diverse and getting more so, so the demographics are moving in favour of Khan. In an off year election voters will often want to punish the government, and so vote for the other party. Boris Johnson was a particularly popular personality, and so managed to overcome all of this, but Goldsmith does not have the same characteristics. Khan is an unspectacular but solid candidate, with none of the obvious flaws that Livingstone had, so we would expect in this election between two competent but unspectacular candidates, the fundamentals will out. Current polling favours Khan, ahead in every poll conducted so far by comfortable margins. The SV electoral system means that it will likely go to a second round, in which case the large ukip and green votes will almost all go to goldsmith and khan respectively and cancel each other out. The handful of Galloway voters will go Khan. Goldsmith probably needs to win almost all the LD second preferences to have a chance, but this seems  v unlikely. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_mayoral_election,_2016 The national picture is not so rosy for Labour, Jeremy Corbyn is unpopular, but much less so in London, so I do not believe he will be a large drag on Khan's candidacy.

London is a multicultural city. Though there are Conservative areas i believe that Labour will take this based on the weakness of Zac Goldsmiths campaign, where he appeals mainly to the well off who do not dominate the city. I find it useful to look at demographics.  Taking a look at London's population, reported number in 2015 was 8.6 million. (The 2011 Census counted 8,173,941 people.)    44% of the city's people are of black or ethnic minority origins.  45% white Brits and the rest other white.   (Census breakdown was 59.8% White; 20.9% Asian and mixed-Asian; 6.6% Indians; Pakistanis and Bangladeshis at 2.7% each; Chinese 1.5%; Arabs 1.3%; 4.9%e classified as "Other Asian;" 15.6%Black and mixed-Black. RECENT ELECTIONS:
In the 2015 general elections, 73 seats in London were contested. In contrast to the results in the UK and particularly England, Labour came first in London and won 62% of seats. Labour achieved their best result in Greater London since 2001.  
2015 general elections, London - popular vote: 43.7% Labor, 34.9% Cons, 7.7% Lib Dem
2010 General Elections, London - 36.6% Labor, 34.5% Cons, 22.1% Lib Dem
2005 general elections, London - 38.9% Labor, 31.9% Cons, 21.9% Lib Dem. Looking at these numbers, and at recent polls, Khan still has the advantage.

YouGov poll from Jan. 4-6 has Khan up by 10 points on both the first and second rounds.   ON GOLDSMITH - 
Member of the prominent Goldsmith family, aristocrat which may give him an advantage. Early career spent working in think-tanks and as editor of The Ecologist magazine.
Deputy chairman of the Conservative Party's Quality of Life Policy Group
Environmentalist PROPOSALS: 
Opposes expansion of Heathrow; vowed to continue investment in public transport.
Favors 'right-to-buy' schemes for buying homes
Wants to expand housing stock through low-density, low-rise construction.
Eurosceptic, though supports the Conservative Party policy of trying to renegotiate the UK's membership of the EU.  ON SADIQ KHAN-
Human rights lawyer.
Was elected to Parliament as MP for Tooting in 2005 general election.
Was campaign manager for Ed Miiliband's bid to become Labour Party leader.
His Muslim religion may be a potential barrier to election (a poll that didn't mention him by name revealed that 31% of Londoners would be 'uncomfortable' with a Muslim mayor.
Other think that electing a Muslim could help London become recognized as a more cosmopolitan city. PROPOSALS: 
London 'living rent'; a quota system for ethnic minority officers in the Metropolitan Police
Increased home building and a campaign for a London Living Wage. Here, we will have to take a closer look at the electorate in the city of London.  For now, I will give the advantage to Khan based on YouGo.

My thought process:
Early on I accepted  @einsteinjs analysis at 90% Khan as correct. I think the race, on paper, is tighter than that.  Here's an article shilling for Goldsmith to make it appear close:   http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/zac-goldsmith/12153494/Zac-Goldsmith-must-unleash-his-inner-maverick-to-be-the-London-Mayor.html There are numerous on the one hand and OTOH items that may or may not be important. (e.g. the last Muslim mayor Lutfur Rahman was corrupt, Khan's a Muslim, but Khan doesn't come from wealth, but Goldsmith votes against his party and is a Eurosceptic, but the Prime Minister referendum is a couple weeks after this so election so it'll be easy to tie Goldsmith to the party, and on and on )  I don't think Goldsmith SOUNDS like a credible Mayor of London.

The odds I am giving are based on the following factors, based on stats retrieved from yougov and shown on wikipedia
( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_mayoral_election,_2016#Electoral_system ). Yeah, I know Wikipedia is unreliable. a) SK is ahead on the polls but without majority (he only has 45%), ZG has 35%, so a second round will be needed.  b) As for the second round, I am assuming the follwoing:
   -  the voters the other left wing parties (Green and Respect Party candidates) have stated SK as second choice
   -  the Lib-Dem voters will have chosen ZG as second choice
  -  the UKIP voters will have chosen ZG as second choice. Under those circumstances I assign the following odds: - 0% for Other, as only ZG and SK are the only ones that can get a majority on first round, or go through to a second round  (very likely scenario) -80% for SK- he is ahead of the polls (with 45%, I could even get it on first round!) and has the advantage on second round vote distribution -20% for ZG- he can be the winner if UKIP or LD  has a larger than expected voting. Factors that can invalidate this forecast: - polls showing SK growing (make SK probablity higher)
- polls showing UKIP or Libdem growing (maks ZG probability higher)
Things are hard to predict, especially the future

It probably is tighter than it seems. Four months away from election in 2008, polling got Lab wrong by 7% and Con wrong by 3%.  There are things that might come into play: the usual turnout thing - Zac is heavily favorited by older people; Zac is tall and handsome; Sadiq is a Muslim.

Here's my thesis: Global deflation resulting from Central Bank QE leading to massive over-investment & currency crisis Given my propensity of A LOT of uncertainty and volatility ahead, which candidate is going to have an advantage?
Basically, of the top two candidates are looking at this scenario, which one is going to make people vote for them?

Here's my scenario: 
.........(a) negative sovereign rates ( Japan, German, Switzerland, etc etc ) 
.........(b) yuan devaluation ( smart money around 30-40% devaluation by the end of the year ) 
.........(c) China's liquidity crunch in foreign-exchange reserves ( approx. $3.23 trillion maybe 1/2 what's needed ) 
.........(d) deflationary oil pricing from massive oversupply driving down U.S. industrial sector and spreading into debt market as energy companies fail around the world 
.........(e) U.S. treasuries rates going negative along with the rest of sovereign debt (bad sign of deflation ) 
.........(f) Major bank (i.e. Deutsche Bank) defaults or else liquidating it's equity so as not to default (i.e. stock value of $1) and Germany having to step in to back it to stop an all out backing crisis and run on the bank 
.........(g) Global Currency Crisis: China's $3.5 trillion banking problem that needs to be unwound in a low/no liquidity environment

Historically mayor us apart from the government of the day (living stone, Johnson) - you just have to be popular, and be seen to represent the city. This means Labour's party travails is less of an issue.

Sadie Khan is popular, and a Londoner. Goldsmith is popular too, but ultimately born rich. He is not a man of the people. I think that will be the deciding factor.

Khan isn't a particularly well-known or charismatic politician, but he's a Labour candidate for mayor in a predominantly Labour city, perhaps the only place where Corbyn's leadership of the party might be seen as anything other than a liability. Boris's two election victories were won against the backdrop of a spectacularly unpopular Labour government (08) and a bitter, divisive Ken Livingstone campaign (2012). This time, the Conservatives will have been in power for 6 years by the time of the election, and despite a very healthy national polling lead, are vulnerable to a protest vote in London. 
Goldsmith has the same weaknesses as Khan, but without Boris's pre-existing national profile.

If Khan the Sensible Labourite (cf. Bill Clinton) can continue to distance himself from Labour's illustrious leader--the really crazy version of Bernie Sanders--he should cruise into office.  Probably he should stop accusing the Tories of being anti-Islamic, though; sounds whiny.
after @Tetbury  analysis and @nirsoffer risk assessment I'm not taking the odds on favorite 64% to 36% any more.   64-36 the opposite way to overcompensate for being WAY wrong early

It might be expected that an election for London Mayor would attract a protest vote coming a year after a General Election in which the Conservatives won (unexpectedly) and Labour did badly, but while a very Old Labour (Corbyn) was elected the new party leader with strong support grass roots support the elections for the labour mayoral candidate seem to have stuck with a Milliband type candidate (SK). So I don't expect any radical candidate to break through in London. The Mayor actually has few powers except for transport so the election is unlikely to attract voters who expect to change the world. The problems that the Labour Party has with splits in policies, although these are not particularly policies related to the job of mayor, are likely to reduce the enthusiasm of Labour supports who might struggle to understand what Labour now stands for.  ZG is another rich posh boy, that sounds like a disadvantage in a city that naturally leans left but Boris got elected twice. We also need to take account of the fact that Labour supporters are easier to find on the street and more likely to be polled than Conservative supporter, so opinion polls are not reliable.

I looked at the change of seats in the 2015 general elections. The percentage of votes labour and the conservatives received in london became my prior. I updated those with the September poll in yougov which had khan receiving 29% and Goldsmith receiving 28%. I then calculated the bayesian probability for each. The difference was 7%. I then gave this 7% lead to Khan in my forecast.
The current Mayor, Boris Johnson, has done an excellent job. He is a conservative: As is Goldsmith.

Although neither candidate has impressed to date, Sadiq seems to have a visible campaign up-and-running, receiving broadly positive coverage in the Evening Standard. Zac's strategy may well be a more concentrated burst of action closer to the polling date but at this stage it seems more like a lack of nous. Boris has shown that being a posh Tory isn't electoral kryptonite in London so it's not all doom and gloom for Zac but the key difference was Boris's x-factor. Zac, while likeable and competent, hasn't demonstrated he has the charisma needed to overcome the taint that his party and background will represent for many voters. And the polls have been going in the right direction for Sadiq which hopefully are putting more effort into getting Tories into their sampling than in 2015 http://www.lbc.co.uk/sadiq-khan-winning-race-to-be-london-mayor-poll-122690 Given that London swung more towards Labour than most of the country in the general election (though less than hoped for in some of the more suburban constituencies) and the fact that a considerable proportion of new surge in Labour members has been in the capital, it may lead to a more energised campaign behind Sadiq. If Zac gets a decent campaign up-and-running then I'd be inclined to bump him up a few points. And there's always the risk that Corbyn goes into meltdown. Though Sadiq has done quite a bit to portray himself as the business-friendly candidate, a well-targeted campaign on that angle could sway a few who remain unconvinced by Sadiq, who isn't an impressive public speaker. But at this moment, it looks like Sadiq should win comfortably.
Although polls put SK ahead of ZG, the Labour bias of polls as shown in the general election makes me compensate in favour of ZG. ZG also campaigns against EU, a view that seems to be strengthening.

Supposing polls are right 90% of the time (looking for supporting data in this regard, but thought i'd make a prediction first) and they are predicting SK wins, I start with a discounted base rate of 65% as there are still 3 months before the election and many things can happen in between to change where the votes swing.
I adjusted the probability upward (10%) as the Labour party seem to have strong support in London, consistent with the notion of an urban-rural political divide in US, UK, and Canada, which had become starker recently. I also see SK's working class background and ethnicity as advantageous traits for garnering additional popular support, and a factor in mobilizing otherwise apathetic voters, at the same time, ZG's socio-economic background may isolate him from voters who do not share the same privileges, in combination, I assign a higher likelihood (5%) of SK's election.
In terms of policy, SK's platform seem more comprehensive and detailed, and aim more towards affordability; ZG's seem more abbreviated, for anyone who actually look at the policies to make a decision, I think a better laid out plan would appeal to a completely neutral voter (2% for SK?). I know very little about UK elections, and am wary because most of my instincts are likely to be wrong.  But I'll record them just to see.  Khan seems to be an up-and-comer.  He has that up-and-comer look, and also he nominated Corbyn.  But quick googling reveals there are 35 MPs who nominated Corbyn so perhaps not as great a glory as I imagined.   http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/who-are-the-morons-who-nominated-jeremy-corbyn-for-the-labour-leadership-contest-10406527.html Goldsmith has the more aristocratic sounding name, went to Eton. The last guy, Boris Johnson is an Old Etonian.  Normally I'd view as a plus for the UK but apparently that's not necessarily the case (it's a live debate). http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/oct/02/zac-goldsmith-sadiq-khan-london-mayor Quick scan, the press seems fairly negative on Labour and Corbyn, but it could biased because Corbyn is quite left.  I know the papers in the UK tend to be more overtly partisan, and I might have caught the right-leaning papers. http://www.economist.com/news/britain/21664385-labour-selects-sadiq-khan-its-candidate-london-mayor-confirming-partys-shift-left
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/Jeremy_Corbyn/12087246/Labour-voters-are-losing-faith-in-Jeremy-Corbyn.html This analysis (looks rigorous) says Labour is doing poorly everywhere but in London. http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/elections/2016/01/how-jeremy-corbyns-labour-faring-elections-so-far Pollwise Khan seems to be having a slight lead on Goldsmith.  There's chatter along the lines that if Labour can't win in London, they can't win anywhere.  I don't think Labour is routing yet.  So I'll have to give the advantage to Labour in this question pending more research.
Khan is a liberal in a liberal city.

Plus here distinguishing himself frim Corbyn http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/12103480/Sadiq-Khan-Pick-me-as-next-London-Mayor.html, but think Zacs smart to mention housing as No1 priority http://www.planningresource.co.uk/article/1380125/goldsmith-pledges-30000-londoners-first-homes, but imagine this may be found out a highfalutin in cross examination as per http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/zac-goldsmiths-campaign-for-london-mayor-sounds-great-but-the-devil-is-very-much-in-the-detail-a6821736.html and easy enough for Sadiq to say: me too, housing is key and by the way I came from a council estate so know what that actually means Zac. In contrast to the results in the United Kingdom, and particularly England, Labour came first in the capital, and won 62% of seats. Labour achieved their best result in Greater London since 2001."

Knowing nothing about it, I'll start with bookies:

Coming in with 91% for Khan. I thought I'd be a little bold on this one (though it's early on in this IFP and after the next few days, it could be that SK settles in around 91% on here *shrugs*). The link shared by @AndrewSabisky (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/96940) was very helpful. Let's take a  closer look with some quotes. Jan 10: "London mayor race: can Zac Goldsmith catch Sadiq Khan?" --> http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/jan/10/london-mayor-race-can-zac-goldsmith-catch-sadiq-khan Were you entering the New Year hoping to become London’s next mayor, you’d almost certainly want to be Sadiq Khan. An array of polls, pundits and bookmakers are predicting that the Labour candidate will succeed Boris Johnson following the election on 5 May while none are doing the same for the only one of his rivals with a realistic chance of beating him, the Conservative Zac Goldsmith.  While Khan has given the impression of covering every angle with know-how and energy, the Goldsmith campaign has, by comparison, looked lethargic and at times ill-judged. The latest voter survey, by YouGov for LBC, gave the Labour man a ten-point lead over the Tory when respondents were invited to pick between just the two of them, an increase of four points from when the same company last asked the same question towards the end of November. Back in October, the pair were neck and neck by that measure.  The signs, then, are that Khan is on course for victory. But there’s a long way still to go and a wide range of reasons why the outcome of this year’s race for City Hall is hard to foresee with certainty. It already looks very different from those that have gone before and part of its fascination is the constellation of factors that could affect the contest either way.
[...]
Election analyst Lewis Baston has written: “For Goldsmith to win, one of two things has to happen – either he manages what Johnson did and gets a vote that a ‘generic Tory’ could not win, or Labour’s national popularity collapses.” He tells me he thinks Jeremy Corbyn as Labour leader is likely to continue to play better in London than in the rest of the country. The current figures bear that out. Yet both Goldsmith and Khan are very mindful that Corbyn could still be a liability for the Labour man. 
~~~ COMMENT: So, the "analysis" seems to indicate that the only way for Goldsmith to win is if something can have an effect on Khan's campaign. Notably, Corbyn. That seems weak to me. Sure, Corbyn is a bit of a loose cannon, but I doubt that he says/does something in the next few months -- especially with the impending Brexit referendum -- that sways the support away from Khan that much. Another important link to follow is Wiki's collection of all the opinion polls for this race --> https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London_mayoral_election,_2016#Opinion_polls It's early, sure, but as was said early on in the Guardian article, things are looking good for Khan.

London vote share in last general election (44%/35% : Lab/Con) - London is a Labour stronghold even in an absolutely shocking year nationally for Lab
London 2012 Mayoral (52%/48% : Con/Lab) - pretty close, despite the Churchillian Boris being head and shoulders above (from a campaign standpoint) Red Ken Starting position: 65% Lab (Base + c.10%) Goldsmith's feuds with Cons (e.g. over Heathrow) move him even further away from non Richmond voters, and doing a poor job at engaging with mainstream electorate. As UK continues with sluggish recovery, and Khan (son of a bus driver) brings more emotive votes in the door, this combined could add another c.10% to probability. Caution risk: I am cautious on going further than 75% since Goldsmith is immensely wealthy and this has a habit of making the difference in elections globally over the past hundreds of years,

Traditionally London is more of a Labour stronghold than a Tory one. However, the two previous mayors (Ken Livingstone, Independent and then Labour; and Boris Johnson, Tory) have flourished by being - either actually, in Ken's first term, or perceived as independent or quasi-independent of their party machines.  Both were "larger than life" characters, too.  None of which really applies to Goldsmith or Khan (will whoever wins become the first London Mayor to be more commonly referred to by their surname than their forename, too...)  Khan is kind of on the left of the Labour party - which in London largely counts in his favour (the suburbs that are also included in the mayoralty? a bit less so),  - he was selected as mayoral candidate in the same poll and by the same voters that made Corbyn party leader; and Labour party membership has expanded particularly rapidly in London in response to Corbyn. Not that that necessarily has any resonance with the wider electorate (and in fact may repulse at least as many as it attracts)... Goldsmith appeals on the environmental front (although would he take second preference votes from Greens? As a conservative, highly unlikely). Tory party is much less active on the ground in London, its membership seems to be smaller. Boris won by reaching out well beyond traditional Tory voters to those who were fed with Ken's far-left posturing and other of his policies. Not yet convinced (despite having placed a bet on him so doing months ago....) than Goldsmith can do the same.
Giving a slight edge to Khan based on current polling lead.

London is a Labour stronghold, and if anything has become more so. It's more or less the only place in the country that, in aggregate, probably doesn't mind Jeremy Corbyn as Labour leader (elsewhere he is very widely regarded as a naive idiot). Khan is a solid candidate with no obvious blots on his record, and provided he doesn't screw up, he should win. Yes, Tory Boris Johnson won the last two mayoral elections, but Boris is an exceptional politician with a gift for being liked that manages to cross political divides. Zac is a good retail politician, as well as being smart & likeable (he took a marginal seat in Richmond and over 2 elections has turned it solidly Tory), but Boris he is not.  Current polls indicate a decent lead for Khan (http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2016/jan/10/london-mayor-race-can-zac-goldsmith-catch-sadiq-khan). Things could change, but I'll be somewhat surprised if they do. Factor in also that if the Brexit referendum happens in 2016, as I think it will, and a lot of Tory party energy will be directed at the referendum, not at a mayoral election that doesn't matter THAT much and which the Tories may rightly figure they aren't very likely to win away.
